Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Evaluation of screen-printing as a manufacturing technique for MRI coils
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project tackles the key challenges of using screen-printing to manufacture receive coils for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) at a commercial scale. MRI is widely used to establish a broad variety of clinical diagnosis, but suffers from long exam times and a high rate of failure, resulting in high costs. Printed receive coils are flexible, lightweight, conform well to the human body and can be manufactured at an order of magnitude lower costs. With this technology, coils can be designed and printed to fit all patient anatomy, therefore improving image quality and offering superior comfort. These technology offers the potential to increase success rate of MRI exams, speed up procedure time and to enhance clinical workflow. Printed coils will have an impact on the accessibility to MRI, serving a more diverse patient population, such as pediatric and bariatric patients, who currently have limited access to this imaging modality, due to the lack of adequate coils. Overall, this project aims at enabling the fabrication of printed coils, thus contributing to reduce health care costs associated with MRI while significantly improving the quality of patient care.


This SBIR Phase I project investigates critical aspects of characterization of screen-printing MRI coil arrays for clinical use. We have shown that printed and flexible MRI arrays provide diagnostic images, while providing better fit and comfort to patients. Printing electronic materials is a novel manufacturing approach which is used here to fabricate these medical devices. Our goal is to provide coils with size and design customized for the diverse anatomy of patients. In this proposed program, we will evaluate the reproducibility of printing, design strategies and the robustness and lifetime of printed coil arrays. Coil size and geometry have a direct impact on image quality and body coverage. We will study the fundamental limits of coil size and geometry when fabricated using solution processed conductors with lower conductivity than conventional metals. The variations in measured signal-to-noise-ratio and image quality from print to print will be characterized and documented in order to provide a successful model for large-scale and low-cost manufacturing of coil arrays. Finally, the robustness of printed arrays will be tested. The packaging used in our designs are significantly different from the status-quo. Lifetime quantification for arrays used in clinical scenarios is important for a successful business plan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), surface receive coils are placed on the patient’s body to capture the radio signal emitted during the exam, and which contains the data needed to reconstruct the image. In order to optimize image quality, the coils should conform as tightly as possible to the region of interest, while being comfortable enough to be tolerated by the patient during the typically long exams. Before the start of this National Science Foundation (NSF) SBIR Phase I project, coils fabricated by screen-printing had been shown to offer many novel advantages from an academic perspective: flexible and lightweight, they consistently provide an excellent fit to the body, with added patient comfort and at potentially very low cost of fabrication. The objective of this project was to demonstrate that coils can be printed at commercial scale and that their benefits can be delivered in clinical-size prototypes. To do so, this project investigated three critical aspects of printed coils: i) the requirements for large-scale, low-cost fabrication and whether they are met by printing, ii) the performance and safety of clinical-size printed coil prototypes, and iii) the durability and robustness of printed coils.

 

The tolerance and precision needed to print coils within electrical specifications (resonance frequency, impedance) without needing manual fine-tuning were identified. Screen-printing can achieve such a degree of precision, which ensures that printing of coils on a large scale and at very low-cost is feasible.

 

Based on anthropometric data, we identified the range of coil sizes needed to meet clinical needs for every patient, from newborn to large adults. It was determined that printed coils can achieve excellent performance for almost all of the clinically relevant sizes. Typical coils consist in arrays of resonating elements, each of them picking up the signal localized in their vicinity. Usually, clinical coils contain 8 to 32 of these channels. To demonstrate that printed coils can be used for clinical applications, we built a 24-channel printed coil array, consisting of two 12-channel halves, for body imaging of 3-5 year old patients. The Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), a measure of image quality, of the printed coil was overall similar to that of a 32-channel state of the art commercial coil. The printed coil achieved up to 25% better SNR than the commercial coil at the surface of the sample, while being slightly lower (less than 5%) in the center of the sample. The printed coil also passed the safety tests required for clinical use. Over the course of this work, we also considerably improved the electronic circuit connecting the coils with the MRI scanner.

 

Finally, this project investigated the robustness of printed coils to environmental and mechanical constraints typical in clinics. It was shown that, when encapsulated properly, coils can resist long-term exposure to all cleaning and disinfecting solvents. Their performance are also minimally affected by changes in air humidity and temperature. Finally, printed coils were subjected to 46,000 cycles of mechanical bending, with a bending radius of 1mm. Coils flexed this way did not show significant change in performance. These results suggest that printed coils can resist several years of typical clinical use.

 

Overall, this project has achieved its main objectives: the feasibility of using screen-printing to successfully manufacture and commercialize MRI coils for clinical use was validated. It was shown that screen-printing can achieve the desired reproducibility and reliability to manufacture printed coils on a large scale. The main deliverable of the project was accomplished by building and characterizing a 12-channel array. Based on this array, a 24-channel posterior and anterior array was built, with performance similar to a current commercial 32-channel array, while at the same time offering radically improved form factor (lightness, flexibility, thinness). Finally, coils were shown to be resistant the typical conditions they will encounter in a clinical setting. Overall, this project is a great stride towards the commercialization of printed MRI coils. Printed coils have the potential to increase the access of MRI to a wider range of patient population, to speed up the exams and increase their rate of success, thus leading to better quality of care and lower costs.

Modified by: Pierre B Lechene
